Winds ranged from strong SW (in the canyon) E (mouth of the canyon) SE ( 7,000' ridgetops). Snowpack was mushy. North facing at 7,000' was 120cm with wet faceted snow on the ground in North Willow. South and southwest facing slopes at this elevation had patchy snow. No Precipitation at 1300 and pouring rain up to 7,000' upon exit at 1600.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Stability seems pretty good, but problematic layers present in the snow at around 170cm and 136cm (where the CT reacts), where there are sharp transitions in the hardness of the layers and also some graupel and sugary snow present.
Wind keeps changing its direction, but mainly from the west, varying from southwest to northwest and varying in strength. At times there is no wind at all, at other times strong gusts arrive which cause wind loading. Evidence of prior wind loading on the ridge towards Bezbog peak, due to southern winds creating cornices in the typical location at the start of the steep northern slope.
Wind generally dying down slowly, on and off snow of varying intensity and fog in the heavier snowbands.
Stability seems good considering what is present in the snow, and no avalanches from the last storm cycle are observed at this location or the next day (12.03) in the Todorka Peak region (photo from 3rd party does show a small slide on the southeast face of Vihren from 12.03, may be from the more direct sunlight there).
The snow column below the last breakoff point of the CT at 136cm is well bounded and can be taken out as a whole column without breaking apart.
There seems to be no or very little temperature gradient in the snow. What is worrying are the layers which contain graupel and sugary snow, as well as the entire combination of those layers with crusts and huge differences in hardness between adjacent layers.
A large amount of heavy, wet or windloaded snow (or both) and an increase in temperatures, both of which could happen in the next week, could cause a rapid increase in danger and increase the likelihood for larger slides to occur.
Pit done on NW aspect of Flattop Mtn. Chugach Front Range
Pit done on NW aspect of Flattop Mtn. Chugach front Range

-ovc, alltså tunna molnslöjor. Drev i byarna, ssw-vind. Bakom en bulle lägst ut i grytan, borde vara samma som på de stora sluttningarna i närheten. Puder!

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Open feature immediately lee of ridge top, sparse trees at TL, wafer thin crust decomposing with facets underneath down 32cm. CTM/CTH results under crust, no propagation on ECT. Rest of snowpack well consolidated, no test results. Observers JW/PB.
Significant snowpack loss was observed. Creeping in isolated areas is occurring. Mud was observed flowing on top of and with snow in elevations above 7000ft in isolated terrain.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Second snowpit was on a west facing aspect at 8510'. There were some westerly and southwesterly aspects that had a stiffer melt freeze crust up to 4" thick in places that had direct sunlight yesterday.

Pro2 course nearby practice pits had 10-35 cm of newly fallen and wind deposited snow on top. Some nearby pits with thicker top PP/DF layers had reactions on top layers on CT tests but only ECTN test results.

Pit location marked as "20230310 Exam Pit Location" on https://caltopo.com/m/EUD4A .

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: The thick and soft faceted layer under the thick crust really tells the story of how different things are this winter. Normally this location would be baked and riddled with crusts and not have such a layer of facets. With such a thick, strong crust on top of them, I don't think they are a concern

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Generally stable conditions at the moment but a very problematic layer with lots of graupel (especially at the bottom part of that layer) is present, and there is a crust just below that. Both the CT and the ECT react at that location, but not quickly and after the initial fracture, the breakup of the snow is slow and progressive, without any smooth and sudden sliding at this location (Q3). There is no fracture across the entire column during the ECT.
Also, the amount of snow above this layer is not a lot, so any slide on top of it will likely not be very large.
If a large amount of snow falls an weighs a lot on top of the problematic layer, we could have a very nasty scenario with dangerous conditions and the potential for large avalanches.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope;
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: The February Storm Incident

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: I skied behind my house 300' up to the south facing edge of Coyote Moon Golf Course to see if I could get any results on MFcr from the high pressure system this past week before the most recent round of storms. Over a foot of new snow was seen on the entirety of the very short ski to the top from the neighborhood, with some prior wind loading from early in the storm in the few non-treed areas. The clouds broke and wind picked up while digging my pit, but the snow returned and wind died down as I left my pit location. An excellent dozen turns were made before exiting behind the Safeway shopping plaza.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown line profile on a deep persistent slab avalanche that occurred sometime Tuesday night Feb 28. Weak faceted snow near a melt freeze crust was the failure layer that propagated 700' wide with cracks and slope failure another 300', and running downslope to train tracks 800'. This put 20 feet of avalanche debris on train tracks as per railroad avalanche forecaster.

User.name: Steve Reynaud
